# Introduction   
  
This tutorial contains an exercise in which you can demonstrate your Markdown skills. You can find the tutorial for this [here](#https://pandar.netlify.app/post/lifos-eigenesprojekt-eng/).

<!-- Was soll die Einführung genau bedeuten? -->

### Creating a personal project 

There are thousands of ways to practice Markdown, whether it's through a tutorial on YouTube or a cheat sheet on the internet. We also provide you with another opportunity to learn how to create your own project. So let's get started. In order to do our Markdown exercise on LIFOS, you first need to create your own project with the corresponding template. To do this, go to the LIFOS homepage and click on *New Project*. It is very important that you do not create it through the department group, otherwise the group will be flooded with numerous Markdown tutorials.

![](/post/gitlaborientierung_newproject.png)

You only need to click on the **New Project** button here and you will have created a new personal project.

Then a page will open where you will find four options: 

![](/post/gitlaborientierung_newprojectoptions.png) 

Here, click on *Create from template*, as there is a specific template for this Markdown exercise. This makes it a little easier for you. To access the exercise template, you need to click on "Instance". The "Built-in" templates are global templates that are available to every <span style="color: darkred;">GitLab</span> user. You can take a look at them or explore them with a test project another time.

![](/post/gitlaborientierung_newprojectinstance.png) 

After clicking on "Instance", search for the template named **_Markdown Exercise Template_**.
 
![](/post/gitlaborientierung_markdownInstanceTemplate.png) 

You can set the visibility level for this project to Private. This means it will only be visible to you, but since this is just for practice, it's not a problem. We explained visibility levels [here](https://pandar.netlify.app/post/lifos-eigenesprojekt-eng/).

## Structure of the template

In addition to the README, you will find three more files in the template.

![](/post/gitlaborientierung_uebungtemplate.png) 
The file you can practice with is called "Übungsdokument.md". The next section will show you exactly how to modify it. If you click on the file named "OpenScience.pdf", you will see what the final document should look like. The file "Lösung.txt" contains the Markdown solution for the document. You should only look at it if you want to compare it to your finished document or if you really don't know what to do next.

## Editing the Document

To edit the "Exercise Document.md", click on it. Then click on *Open in Web IDE*.

![](/post/gitlaborientierung_openuebunginwebide.png) 

There you can fill the document with your Markdown code under *Edit* and preview how it will look like in the "translated" version under *Preview Markdown*. 

![](/post/gitlaborientierung_webidetemplate.png)

If you have made changes to your README that you want to keep, you can do this in two different ways.

One way is through the **Web IDE**, which we have just opened. We will now make a change to our document.

![](/post/gitlabMarkdown_ÄnderungReadMe.png)

You can preview this change in the "translated" version by clicking on *Preview Markdown*. If you are satisfied with the change, click on *Create commit...* at the bottom left.

![](/post/gitlabMarkdown_CreateCommitWebIDE.png)

You enter a *Commit Message*. This is important to track changes later on. Although the Markdown exercise project is only for your personal use, you might still want to look for the reasons for individual changes you made over time.

![](/post/gitlabMarkdown_CommitTest.png)
As you can see, you can either choose the main branch or create a new branch when committing. Here, you select the main branch by default. If you want to learn more about branches, check out this [tutorial](https://pandar.netlify.app/post/branches/). Your changes are now included in the README.

<!-- Branches waren jetzt im eigene Projekte Teil gar kein Thema mehr - sollte vlt an einer Stelle auch angeschnitten werden. - evtl. im vertiefende Einführung? Hier muss man halt nur den main-Branch auswählen, weil die default Option ist einen neuen zu erstellen (bei jedem Commit) und das wollen wir ja nicht.-->

Another option would be to download the README file to your computer, make the changes there, and then upload the updated README file using the "Update" button. Make sure to stay on the **main** branch when uploading! 

If you think your document matches the template, you can compare it with the "Lösung.txt" file to see if you did everything correctly. 
 

### Deleting a project

As mentioned earlier, deleting projects that belong to a group is not possible for students. However, since the Markdown exercise project is personally assigned to you, you have the permission to delete it. Here's a general description of how to delete projects:

First, go to the project you want to delete (e.g. the completed Markdown tutorial). Then, click on *Settings* in the sidebar, and then on *General*:

![](/post/gitlabMarkdown_DeleteProject.png)

Here you need to scroll down until you see *Advanced*.

![](/post/gitlabMarkdown_AdvancedPrjectSet.png)

Once you've expanded it, scroll to the very end of the page. Here you will find the button that allows you to delete your project. 

![](/post/gitlabMarkdown_DeleteProjectButton.png)
As it says under the button, you must be 100% sure whether you want to delete the project or not.

After you've confirmed the security prompt, you can delete your project. 

![](/post/gitlabMarkdown_DeleteProjectCheck.png)

Depending on whether you have a <span style="color: darkred;">GitLab</span> version above 13.2 or below that version, the project will be immediately deleted or the status of your project will change to "pending deletion". This status is another security check that provides a period of time (7 days) after deletion during which the project can be restored. During this time, no one except the project members can see the project. For versions of <span style="color: darkred;">GitLab</span> above 13.2, the default status is "immediate project deletion".

If you need an immediate deletion of a project because you uploaded personal data or similar, please contact the [central support of LIFOS](mailto:lifos@uni-frankurt.de).

## Conclusion
As you can see, Markdown offers you a variety of ways to make your READme look appealing. In this tutorial, we covered the basic basics that you definitely need. However, Markdown offers many more possibilities, such as coloring text or creating tables. For this, the [Markdown documentation](https://www.markdownguide.org/extended-syntax/) for "Extended Syntax" is recommended.

### Appendix A

<details><summary> **R-Markdown** </summary> 

#### Installation

The difference between Markdown and R-Markdown is very simple. With R-Markdown, you can edit documents (like your READme) in R, everything is based on Markdown, but you can also insert R code chunks.

To use R-Markdown, you have to install it first and implement it in your file.
This works with:

`install.packages("rmarkdown")`

and then:

`library(rmarkdown)`

#### R-Code

To insert R code into your document, follow these steps: 

```{r}
mean(c(5,6,7,8,9))     
```

```{r eval = F}
mean(c(5,6,7,8,9))     
```

The R code must work. If you write something here that would not work in a normal R session, an error message will be displayed. The result of your expression is displayed below the R code.

You can also create plots:

```{r eval = F}
werte <- c(1, 3, 6, 4, 9)

plot(werte)

```
Otherwise, everything works like in the "regular" Markdown tutorial.

</details>
